bibl.title: Letter from Jennie Wilson to the Editor of Youth's Companion, January 21, 1907

div1.p: Wilson writes to the Editor concerning the situation of Kissinger. She hopes that something can be done for him.

div1.head: Letter from Jennie Wilson to the Editor of Youth's Companion, January 21, 1907
div1.opener:
Walter Reed
ans
-- COPY --
South Whitley, Ind.,
January 21, 1907.
Editor, Youth's Companion,
Boston, Mass.
My dear Sir:-
div1.p:
The article, “Lessons From Little Things,” on page 15
of The Companion for Jan. 10, was very interesting to me because I
am well acquainted with John R. Kissinger, one of the heroes who
submitted to being bitten by fever-infected mosquitoes.

I have seen the chart on which the record of his fever
was kept, also the fine watch on which his name and the words, for
courage, were inscribed. This watch was presented to him by the
surgeons with whom he was associated.

The article in your paper states that he made a complete
recovery and it was thought that he had, but he has been much
afflicted during the last three years, and the physicians think
it is from the effect of yellow fever. For several months he has
been unable to walk on account of spinal trouble, and he is in poor
financial circumstances.

He has married since the war, and now resides at 606,
Keasey St., South Bend, Indiana.

Although he cannot walk he gets on his knees and helps
do washing, which he and his wife take in to earn money.

He has not been able to get a pension as yet, because it
seemed that he fully recovered from the yellow fever.

It seems so sad, and I felt that I wanted to tell you
about his condition.
